title: 107_s148
content: The "Hope for Children Act" is the short title of this legislation. It aims to expand adoption credit and adoption assistance programs. The "Hope for Children Act" expands adoption credit under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. It allows a credit for qualified adoption expenses paid or incurred by the taxpayer, with a higher amount of $10,000 for the adoption of a child with special needs. Adoption assistance programs are also amended to exclude gross income of an employee. The "Hope for Children Act" amends the Internal Revenue Code to exclude employer-paid adoption expenses from an employee's gross income. The exclusion amount is based on qualified adoption expenses, with a higher limit of $10,000 for children with special needs. Adoption credit is increased to cover these expenses. The "Hope for Children Act" increases the adoption assistance program limits to $10,000 and removes the special needs distinction. The "Hope for Children Act" increases adoption assistance program limits to $150,000, amends income limitations, and allows the adoption credit for children with special needs in the year of finalization. Sunset provisions are repealed. Sunset provisions are repealed, and adjustments are made for inflation in dollar and income limitations for adoption expenses. The Code of 1986 is amended to adjust dollar amounts for inflation in adoption expenses starting from December 31, 2002. Adoption assistance programs under Section 137 are also amended to include new provisions. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to adjust dollar amounts for inflation in adoption expenses starting from December 31, 2002. This includes increasing dollar amounts in specific subsections and paragraphs based on the cost-of-living adjustment for the calendar year. Additionally, limitations based on the amount of tax are also revised under Section 23(c) of the Code. Additionally, limitations based on the amount of tax are revised under Section 23(c) of the Code, through "1400C)" and inserting "the applicable tax limitation." The term "applicable tax limitation" is defined as the sum of the taxpayer's regular tax liability for the taxable year, reduced by certain credits and the tax imposed by section 55 for the taxable year. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to adjust dollar amounts for inflation in adoption expenses starting from December 31, 2002. Section 53(b)(1) is amended to reduce the minimum tax credit by the aggregate amount taken into account under section 23(d)(3)(B) for prior taxable years. These amendments apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 2001.
